entry.title: Whether Tax amount will be included Inventory Cost in US procurement process.
entry.content:
Whether inventory cost in every US procurement will include the tax amount? 

Tried with other region like Japan, Australia and Singapore, but is there any possibility that country US having this scenario of Tax inclusion in the inventory cost.



------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Whether Tax amount will be included Inventory Cost in...
entry.content: Basically the inventory cost represents the value assigned to a material's quantity held in stock. It's calculated by multiplying the inventory quantity by the inventory cost per unit. Ideally tax cannot be included here because this cost is used to determine the value of inventory and to value movements of the material.

entry.title: Re: Which Certification is beneficial along with SAP IBP?
entry.content:
Hi @Mukesh_Bhutekar 
Please check our SAP CERTIFICATION C_IBP SAP Certified Associate - SAP IBP for Supply Chain site.
This certification verifies that you posses the core skills in the area of the SAP supply chain planning and proves that you have an overall understanding within this consultant profile of the industry solutions, and can implement this skills practically in projects under the guidance of an experienced consultant. It is recommended as an entry-level qualification to allow consultants to get acquainted with the the cores of SAP Integrated Business Planning.
Kind regards
Margit

entry.title: Re: Withholding tax for customer invoice in Italy #COE#RFL01
entry.content:
Since this is a legal requirement, you can submit an Expert Configuration request to SAP via the support portal.

Now, coming to your requirement on the sales side, if the required configuration is missing, you can do on your own.
Create a condition type and set to statistical, to calculate the withholding tax amount. By setting the condition type as statistical, it won't have any financial impact but you can make the value visible in invoice output. On the other hand, if your Business stakeholders from Finance side agree to have this financial posting, either you don't mark as statistical or set to Accrual depending upon the Business requirement. One advantage of setting the condition type as accrual is, when an incoming payment is posted, this value can also be adjusted parallelly and you have a track on this.

entry.title: Datasphere - HANA Cloud DB Remote Table (Insufficient privileges on HDI)
entry.content:
Hi experts,

We have created a connection in Datasphere to visualize the access to a HANA Cloud DB.

The set up is correct and we are able to import the relevant tables as remote tables but when we are trying to view the data we are getting the error as follows:

internal error: Error opening the cursor for the remote database <DWC_IL_BTP_HANA_APPS_EU.HANA_BTP_APPS_EU> [SAP AG][LIBODBCHDB SO][HDBODBC] General error;258 insufficient privilege: Detailed info for this error can be found with guid 'E3A628E32FA90D4B90B99370A3C9CBC4'

The issue is due to insufficient privileges of the user used in the Datasphere connection (DBAMIN) to access the HDI container where the table exist.

I understand that to solve the issue we need to assigned SELECT privilege to DBADMIN on the respective schema but, how can we do that?

Note that the HDI container has been created over an MTA so not sure how we can do to grant that permission.

Many thanks!

C.

entry.title: Re: Session 1 Recap & Highlights– Data Inspired – Successful concepts for data-driven organizati
entry.content:
‘It is thus evident that the value of ICT as enabler of service of service delivery will not be realised without incorporating governance of ICT in the corporate governance regime of a department.’

The Context of Alignment 

 

Alignment is the delivery of required results.

To line up IT with business plans requires the adoption of a language used in dealing with financial matters. Alignment is the capacity to demonstrate a positive relationship between information technologies and the accepted measures of performance.  Computer investments must show as enhancements to a business plan. Executives should measure what, how and when it supports improvements in the delivery of operating results.

What is alignment?

 

Aligning information systems to corporate goals has emerged as the number one concern for over a decade(s) in surveys of information systems executives. For the public sector it means support in the delivery of superior services to the public.

 

Expectations must precede the choice of technologies

 

To achieve alignment, one must first identify the sources of misalignment. If profitability or performance does not meet expectations, there must be enumerable reasons why this is so. There is no point in picking the latest technologies as a remedy, if the problem is curable by changing management practices.  Such action may not require computers at all. It may call for investing in people rather than technology. How much to spend comes only after one answers; What are the benefits?.

In the absence of trustworthy metrics, the current corporate and public sector practice is not to budget computers according to specified results, but according to the perceived needs of its proponents. (It follows the bureaucrat’s first principle of keeping a job: Do not commit to what you will deliver, but insist on getting what you ask for).  Consultants and government bureaucrats reinforce this bias by offering advice on best practices for managing inputs in the hope that it will somehow yield superior outputs.

The effects of IT investments are observable only by comparing how a particular organisation performs differently with or without added computer investments.

 A difference between top-performing organisations and their competitors is the ability to generate large returns on IT investments. The difference can be traced to effective usage of IT governance to support business strategies. Effective IT governance consists of leadership and organisational structures and processes that ensure that the organisation’s IT sustains and extends the organisation’s strategies and objectives.

The governance structures (decision-making structures such as committees, councils and senior management roles) act like the Social Operating Mechanism (SOM) of the organisation, ensuring information flow, working relationships, transparency and cross - functional collaboration. Along with the processes and communication tools, they act like the social operating system of the organisation, driving its culture and embedding it in the DNA of the organisation by promoting proper accountability, desirable behaviours and cultural values.

Once the governance structures, processes and tools are deployed and institutionalised within the organisation, silos and redundancies are eliminated. Accountabilities, roles and responsibilities are firmly established. The business units within the organisation are better able to exchange information, align and collaborate efficiently.

The organisation becomes lean, mean and more efficient. This leads to effectiveness in the overall governance, performance and productivity of the organisation.

The Five IT Governance Focus Areas

 

The purpose of IT governance can be categorised by the five IT governance focus areas, which encompass the entire gamut of scope and issues that management needs to address in order to govern IT effectively:

  • Strategic alignment:
    • Ensure alignment among IT and business unit goals.
    • Perform strategic and tactical planning to align to business requirements so that IT does not work in silos.
  • Value delivery:
    • Deliver high-quality work and exploit opportunities.
    • Manage, deliver and maximise business benefits and value.
    • Ensure that business requirements are met.
  • Risk management:
    • Institute a risk management framework to embed risk management responsibilities in the organisation.
    • Manage and remediate risk factors and issues, including risk and issue assessment, alignment, awareness, analysis, response and monitoring.
  • Resource management:
    • Manage IT resource demand and supply effectively and efficiently.
    • Ensure on-time procurement and supply of resources.
  • Performance measurement:
    • Measure, monitor and control IT performance using appropriate metrics and key performance indicators (KPIs). This can be done by instituting an IT balanced scorecard.
    • Continually improve IT performance to achieve business requirements and goals.

IT Governance Model Problem

 

In obsolete and ineffective governance models, the governance structures are not balanced, not set up properly and/or do not function properly. This leads to ineffective social operating mechanisms (SOM) of the organisation, resulting in a lack of communication, collaboration and dissemination of information flow.

Consequently, the different business units and functions of the organisation do not share information effectively because they work and function in a siloed manner. A duplication of roles and responsibilities among the different functions and business units of the organisation ensues and, as a result, leads to high operating costs and lower margins. In short, the organisation functions in a reactive manner and is slow to respond to macro and micro economic changes.

Thus, the major problems noted due to ineffective (or even the absence of) governance models are:

  • A siloed IT organisation with misalignment among IT and business unit goals
  • Lack of accountability and ownership
  • Limited and ineffective communications
  • Ineffective risk and issue management
  • Poor-quality deliverables
  • Customer dissatisfaction

Other problems frequently encountered include:

  • Failure to deliver promised benefits
  • Return on investment (ROI) different than expected
  • Ending projects prematurely
  • Serious operational IT incidents

  ‘Realm of Possibility’

 

It is important for the organisation to become a lean, mean and well-oiled machine. In support toward this ontological approach, redesigning or modernising governance models is necessary.

The major task while redesigning governance models is to ensure ownership, accountability, communication, cross- functional collaboration, and alignment between the business and IT. Many times governance models are implemented, but miss the big picture by focusing on a few important requirements and missing the others.

The ontological approach is uniquely effective in providing actionable access to being a leader and exercising leadership effectively. While ontology as a general subject is concerned with the being of anything, here we are concerned with the ontology of human beings (the nature and function of being for human beings). Specifically, we are concerned with the ontology of leader and leadership (the nature and function of being for a leader and the actions of effective leadership).

 

When one is being,  a leader shapes one’s perceptions, emotions, creative imagination, thinking, planning, and consequently one’s actions in the exercise of leadership.

 

 

 

Being a leader and the effective exercise of leadership as one’s natural self-expression does not come from learning and trying to emulate the characteristics or styles of noteworthy leaders, or learning what effective leaders do and trying to emulate them (and most certainly not from merely being in a leadership position, or position of authority).

If you are not being a leader and you try to act like a leader, you are likely to fail. That’s called being inauthentic (playing a role or pretending to be a leader), deadly in any attempt to exercise leadership.

An epistemological mastery of a subject leaves you knowing. An ontological mastery of a subject leaves you being.

Gaining access to being a leader and the effective exercise of leadership as one’s natural self-expression also requires dealing with those factors present in all human beings that constrain each person’s freedom to be – and constrain and shape one’s perceptions, emotions, creative imagination, thinking, planning, and actions. When one is not constrained or shaped by these factors – what we term “ontological constraints” – one’s way of being and acting results naturally in one’s personal best. We work with the public sector staff so that they accomplish this for themselves.

The Underlying Theory

  

Three Foundational Elements of Leadership

Integrity (in our model a positive phenomenon):

  • Being whole and complete – achieved by “honouring one’s word” (creates workability, develops trust).

Authenticity:

  • Being and acting consistent with who you hold yourself out to be for others and who you hold yourself to be for yourself. When leading, being authentic leaves you grounded and able to be straight without using force.

Being Committed to Something Bigger than Oneself:

  • Source of the serene passion (charisma) required to lead and to develop others as leaders and the source of persistence (joy in the labour of) when the path gets tough.

 

The other main components to address in the design of the governance models are:

  • Governance structures—Also known as governance forums or decision-making structures, these include forums, accountabilities, roles and responsibilities. As mentioned earlier, governance structures facilitate communication, decision making and collaboration among the different business units of the organisation. Without governance structures, the organisation essentially functions in silos.
  • Alignment processes—These processes include strategic, operational, people and exception-handling processes. Alignment processes ensure compliance with policies and provide valuable input for decision making.
  • Metrics—Metrics help in measuring, monitoring and tracking the projects as well as their business value. Both the KPIs and key goal indicators (KGIs) are useful. KPIs help alert the organisation to potential problems early on, and KGIs indicate whether the goals are being met.
  • Communication approaches—Institutionalisation is directly proportional to the amount of communication carried out. Effective communication ensures successful institutionalisation of IT governance and desirable behaviours within the organisation. Toward this objective, communication needs to be completed using a variety of channels, including town-hall meetings, emails, web portals, one-on-one meetings, team meetings and governance forums. Repeated communication is also essential to reinforce the messages.

The objective of the governance models is to improve and standardise the components to achieve the business unit objectives. What is needed is a framework on which the components of the governance models can be built to ensure consideration of the entire gamut of requirements. The five IT governance focus areas (strategic alignment, value delivery, risk management, resource management and performance measurement) described earlier come into play since they describe the main perspectives and requirements that IT management needs to manage and govern effectively to create a balanced system.

Inability to address any of the above and five IT governance focus areas will lead to an unbalanced system and problems later on, as shown in the following examples:

 

 

  • If adequate governance structures do not exist, the organisation’s social operating systems will not function effectively. If governance structures do not exist for performance measurement, the different business units of the organisation will not collaborate effectively and exchange information to measure and manage performance.
  • If metrics do not exist for strategic alignment or risk management, alignment or risk problems will not be known early.
  • If processes do not exist for resource management, problems in resource demand and supply may not be known.

Benefits distinguish Leadership

 

Redesigning governance models by taking into consideration the five IT governance focus areas (strategic alignment, value delivery, risk management, resource management and performance measurement) leads to the following benefits:

  • Governance structures, roles, responsibilities, alignment processes and metrics to address issues under the five IT governance focus areas
  • Removal of silos between the business units of the organisation, leading to effective communication and collaboration
  • Better scope and requirements management
  • Effective measurement, monitoring and management
  • Higher quality of deliverables
  • Customer satisfaction
  • Effective risk and issue management
  • Better decision making
  • A proactive organisation that is quick in responding to market and internal changes

The end result is that the organisation has a balanced social operating system. Effective governance structures, alignment processes and communication approaches result in fluent collaboration, dissemination of information and removal of silos. Consequently, better decisions are made and the organisation becomes proactive in dealing with the macro- and micro economic changes. Thus, the organisation becomes agile, healthy, lean and more productive.

entry.title: picking strategy with quantity classification - PAL CAR EA
entry.content:
Hello,

i hope this is still active. I am configuring a quantity classification PICK strategy in S4 EWM. I have 3 classifications, P(PAL), C(CAR) and 1(EA). This used to work until EWM 9.5, but when I tried this in S4 EWM, PAL is working fine, but for CAR, I always get a decimal carton quantity.

For example, the material has the following UOM: 

PAL = 100 EA

CAR = 10 EA

 

Delivery Quantity is 112 EA. Expectation is to split this into the following breakdown:

P = 100 EA (or 1PAL)

C= 10EA (or 1 CAR)

1 = 2 EA

The actual result is:

P = 100 EA (or 1PAL)

C = 12 EA (1.2 CAR)

I wonder why the CAR classification is getting the remaining 12 EA, when it should be getting 10EA only. Is it a standard bug?

Current Configuration

Packspec - I have 3 levels, EA, CAR and PAL. Each level has quantity classification active with condition record for task Creation (0WHT).

Process Type - WPT 2010 is set to rounding rule = 3 (round down to multiples of a unit)

Pick Strategy - I set 3 different search strategy for each classification

When I check the logs of WT creation, it correctly reads the configuration, but the remaining quantity is being assigned to CAR classification even if it has loose quantity intended for other search strategy.

I hope someone can enlighten.

@EndUserText.label: 'Projection View for Holiday Block'

key DistChn,

key Div,

}

entry.title: Re: Change Warning Message Purchasing document belongs to...
entry.content:
Via oba5, you can change this but before changing, you need to consider the following points which might be very crucial

  • Users will be prevented from posting any down payment request if the vendor in the purchasing document doesn’t match the one entered in F-47.
  • Unlike a warning, users can’t bypass the message—even if the mismatch is intentional or part of a workaround.
  • If your procurement process involves vendor substitutions, shared purchasing documents, or legacy data inconsistencies, this change could lead to frequent interruptions.

If you are aware of all these implications, check whether you need to carry out code corrections as recommended in SAP note 2071834

entry.title: Re: How to perform a year-end closing in S4 HANA Cloud Pu...
entry.content:
Hello @Ismael_Kinesis 

My apologies for the late reply.

Thank you for your follow-up. Your questions are very relevant, and I appreciate your attention to detail. I’ve addressed both below, ensuring the steps are fully aligned with SAP’s best practices for S/4HANA Public Cloud.

a) Correct Sequence Period Closing vs. Balance Carry forward

Yes, the correct order is

  1. Complete all postings (periods 1–12).
  2. Close periods 1–11 in App: Manage Posting Periods (F0717).
  3. Post final year-end entries in period 12.
  4. Close period 12.
  5. Then run Carryforward Balances (F1515).

 All periods must be closed before running the balance carryforward. If period 12 remains open, the carry forward may miss final balances.

b) Closing Cockpit?

There is no integrated Closing Cockpit in standard S4 Public Cloud.

  • Use individual apps (Run Depreciation, Schedule GL Jobs).
  • Optionally, Advanced Financial Closing (AFC) is available as an add-on for process orchestration.

Useful SAP Documentation Reference:

  • SAP Help Accounting and Financial Close
  • Year-End Closing Activities – SAP Best Practices Explorer (Public Cloud)
  • SAP Advanced Financial Closing

Let me know if it helps

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Cloud Transport Management retention period over 30 days
entry.content:
To my understanding, Cloud Transport Management Transports are only being stored for 30 days...

When we're making deployments from DEV --> QA --> PROD,  the whole process takes more than 30 days until each transport is approved by the customer. 

We want to make sure the transports won't get removed while in process to get to PROD. 

The documentation wasn't clear about the statuses (e.g. Initial vs Running, etc..) and how long are the Transports retained.

entry.title: Re: SAC Advanced Formula Iterative Prioritization
entry.content:
@volkancugali 

The long execution times can be attributed to the many For loops constructs used.

Some Alternative approaches

  1. If both A_MAPPING and I_MAPPING exists with the same combination of VLK_PRJ and Date, then I_MAPPING is ignored.

You can avoid a loop by just overwriting I_MAPPING by A_MAPPING ( copy both in right sequence). If A_MAPPING exists, it overwrites else I_MAPPING remains.

2. If multiple combinations are entered for the same combination of VLK_PRJ and date, then the first customer code will be used, rest will not be considered. ( I know this might be handled from input screen, but let's assume user entered multiple combination by mistake )

First customer is subjective here ( I think it will be alphabetical), rather than using a loop every time, either maintain the order in master data or just create a ordered mapping using fact data once and try to reuse that. Best handle it in front end.

3. If there is no mapping entry for the further periods ( I_MAPPING only exists for the starting date, and no A_MAPPING is entered for the next period ), then duplicate it from previous period as it is.

Explore use of CARRYFORWARD function , it may avoid you some loops 

Hope this helps !!

Nikhil

entry.title: Including multiple Matrix Managers in Performance– “User Does Not Exist” Error Despite Valid USERIDs
entry.content:
Hi all,

Similar to @Maria851  in https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/successfactors-create-job-to-run-importing-matrix-and-custom-managers/qaq-p/14136823 and @SatishPanda  in https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-q-a/can-we-assign-two-matrix-manager-to-a-single-employee-in-system/qaq-p/13639437 

We are trying to import matrix managers using the Import Matrix Manager and Custom Manager Relationships tool in SAP SuccessFactors. The process followed is from documentation https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-platform/managing-user-information and using the CSV format with following structure:

USERID,MGR_USERID,RELATIONSHIP,ORG_CHART_DISPLAY,ACTION
1111,2222|3333,EX,TRUE,ADD

Both 1111, 2222and 3333are confirmed as active users in the UDF and visible in the platform. However, I consistently receive this error:

Line number: 1 | Column: MGR_USERID | Cause: The user does not exist in the system.

 

We’ve already:

  • Verified that the USERIDs are active and correctly formatted
  • Ensured the file is UTF-8 encoded
  • Cleaned up any hidden characters or line breaks

Still no success.

Has anyone encountered this before? Could this be related to how the platform validates USERIDs in this tool vs. the UDF? Any insights or workarounds would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance!

Documentation reviewed:

https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-platform/managing-user-information/importing-matrix-and-custom-managers

https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-ec-s4-hcm-integration/implementing-data-migration-and-replication-to-employee-central/how-manager-s-user-id-is-updated

3247460 - Matrix manager and HR manager are unable to sync to

From <https://me.sap.com/notes/3247460/E>

2087507 - Data Imports & Exports: Matrix Manager and Custom Manager Import - Displaying Matrix & Custom Manager

From <https://me.sap.com/notes/2087507/E>

entry.title: Re: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori – Organizing your My Home page
entry.content:
Hi MKGhandhi,

Unfortunately, role changes are irrelevant here.  Personalizations are not saved to your role.  They are personal to that user id only! 

A system refresh will clear them back to where they were when the system was last backed up.  Depending on the type of personalization, they may use the appstate id to capture them so they can be system- and client-specific as well.  If your system is refreshed every week from a months-old backup or is being "refreshed" by copy from another environment, then losing your personalization settings would be expected. 

Personalization is held in the system in what's called the Layered Content Repository, and it's possible to use a program called /UIF/MIGRATE_FES_PERSO to migrate that data, i.e. use a transport to overwrite the current settings.  You can explore that option further in the section Migrate Personalization Data section of the SAP Fiori launchpad administration guide in the SAP Help.  WARNING! This program is primarily intended for extreme changes such as moving from standalone deployment mode to embedded mode.

entry.title: Re: An error "No authorization to view data" when trying...
entry.content:
Hello @Kazuhiro_F 

The error “No authorisation to view data” when previewing A_SALESORDER in Eclipse occurs due to missing business role authorisations for accessing sales order data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Please make sure your user has a role that includes catalogues like

  • SAP_SD_BC_SO_DISP_PC (Sales Order Display)
  • SAP_SD_BC_SO_PROC_MC (Sales Order Processing)

Finding the Required Business Roles and Business Catalogues for a Solution Process

You can check this via the Maintain Business Users app.

Alternatively, for testing, you can use the View Browser (F2170) or the Custom Analytical Queries app to preview the data.

Please inform me if you need any further information.

Best regards,
Chuma

entry.title: Seeking Guidance on Navigating SAP Modules for a Career Transition
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I’m fairly new to the SAP ecosystem and would really appreciate some guidance from the experienced professionals here. I come from a background in finance and operations, and I’ve recently decided to shift my focus toward building a career in SAP. However, I’m currently a bit overwhelmed by the number of modules and specializations SAP offers.

My goal is to choose a module that not only aligns with my previous experience but also has strong long-term career prospects. From what I’ve gathered, modules like SAP FI, CO, MM, and S/4HANA are quite popular — but I’m unsure which direction makes the most sense for someone like me who is just starting out.

Here are a few specific questions I’m hoping to get clarity on:

  • Which module would be a good fit for someone with a finance and operations background?

  • How important is having prior technical knowledge (like programming) when starting with SAP APO training?

  • Are there any beginner-friendly resources or training platforms you’d recommend?

  • Should I focus more on learning ECC or jump straight into S/4HANA?

Any advice, suggestions, or insights you can share would mean a lot. I’m eager to learn and would love to hear about your own experiences in getting started with SAP.

Thank you in advance for your time and support!

entry.title: Re: New asset accounting activation in S4/HANA
entry.content:
Hi @junsang ,

Please try below steps.

1. Execute transaction FAA_CHECK_ACTIVATION or RASFIN_MIGR_PRECHECK (if applicable for your migration scenario). These programs will identify any missing or incomplete configurations. Address all errors reported.
2. Verify that depreciation areas are correctly defined, especially regarding their posting to the General Ledger (e.g., "Area Posts in Realtime" for areas representing parallel accounting principles).
3. Ensure ledger groups are assigned to each depreciation area.
4. Technical Clearing Account for Integrated Asset Acquisitions: Make sure this account is properly created and configured as a reconciliation account for fixed assets. It's crucial for real-time postings.
5. the business function FIN_AA_PARALLEL_VAL needed to be explicitly activated.
6. Manual Activation (if pre-checks are clear and "Active" is still missing). Transaction FAA_DOACTIVATION: In some specific scenarios, especially when an entry might be missing in table TFAAD_BSN_FUNC, you might need to run transaction FAA_DOACTIVATION. Execute FAA_DOACTIVATION. Enter your client number. Execute the transaction.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Custom Field Customer Invoice output
entry.content:
SOLVED: If you need Long Text on the PDF output of your Customer invoice, you post the document in FB60, then you display it in Manage Journal Entries and here you have section "Notes" both in the header and in Line items. Here you fill it with text. Then if you create correspondence, it will appear. 

If it doesn't appear, you have to add .CorrespncAcctgDocNoteTxt attribute in the Adobe LiveCycle Designer to your template (path $.C_FinInvoiceHeaderFDPType.to_HeaderNote.C_FinInvoiceHeaderNoteFDPType[*].CorrespncAcctgDocNoteTxt). 

and for line items:  $.C_FinInvoiceHeaderFDPType.to_Item.C_FinInvoiceItemFDPType[*].to_ItemNote.C_FinInvoiceItemNoteFDPType[*].CorrespncAcctgDocNoteTxt

entry.title: E-mails to specific users based on filters in SAP Cloud ALM Integration & Exception Monitoring
entry.content:
Hello Team,

We are currently setting up email notification for integration and exception monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM.

Could you please let us know if it is possible to send email notification to individual id for a particular filter.

Thanks & Regards,


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: E-mails to specific users based on filters in SAP Clo...
entry.content:
An individual event will need to be created for each set of filters. To do this, follow these steps:

  1. Logon to SAP Cloud ALM.
  2. Open the Integration & Exception Monitoring app. 
  3. Select the "Configuration" menu.
  4. Select the relevant service/system from the list.
  5. Select the "Events" tab. 
  6. Click the "Add" button on the top right of the table.
  7. Enter the mandatory data for the new event.
  8. Select a type.
  9. Specify the filter data.
  10. Specify any further data (e.g. parameters, grouping, etc.). 
  11. Save the event. 
  12. Repeat these steps for each set of filters which must be used for notifications.

This will result in several events for the same system/service, where each event applies a specific set of filters to the collected data. You can then create alerts/notifications for specific users for this data. You can edit the events to enable the alerts and e-mail notifications. The event recipient list can be updated in each filtered event to include only the specific users that should be notified for the specified filters.  

It is currently not possible to "sub-divide" an existing single event so that recipients are decided based on complex criteria in a single event. Instead, multiple events must be used (with their own filters). 

More information is available in these KBAs:

  • 3380695 - FAQ - SAP Cloud ALM (CALM) : Integration & Exception Monitoring
  • 3619487 - Event filtering for SAP Cloud ALM Integration & Exception Monitoring - SAP Cloud ALM
  • 3482250 - How the event setting works for the Integration Monitoring - SAP Cloud ALM

entry.title: SAP Build Apps: Getting data with “Get Record Collection” or maybe “HTTP Destination Request”?
entry.content:
“Get Record Collection”

The most common (and comfortable) way to get data from backend is to use “Get Record Collection” flow function. All we need to do is to install an integration with SAP system via its REST API using SAP BTP Destination.

 

 

 

If we enable the “Autogenerate configuration” option during installation of the integration, we will get even definition of the data structure, ready to use as a template for data variables.

 

 

We can even easily add call parameters, which are to be added to the relative path as a query – all we need is to add additional inputs in the entity definition:

 

These additional inputs will be automatically added in the relative path and in the test section of the data entity. And we can use these additional inputs to send additional parameters with the API call:

 

 

And, as data variable uses in fact “Get Record Collection” flow function in the background, we also can do the same with “Get Record Collection” flow function:

 

 

When “Get Record Collection” is not enough

Sometimes we need some additional information, not only the data itself – we need access to the header of the backend response – something the “Get Record Collection” flow function can’t easily (if at all) provide. And this is the case with getting data from the SAP BTP Auditlog service I wrote about in the previous blog (SAP BTP Global Account audit logs using SAP BTP Auditlog service, SAP Build Apps and SAP Ai Core). The issue with the Auditlog service is hat it does not always send requested data in single run. If the response should contain more data, the Auditlog service will use “paging”. It will send first portion (page) only, and you will have to request next portion of the answer data, and next one, till all the data is received.

How do we know that our application should request next page of data? Auditlog service, when paging is used, adds appropriate information in the response header. If all the data is sent without paging, there is no additional information in the header. But if next page is ready for sending, the Auditlog service will add “paging” field in the response header. This “paging” field has the following structure:

Paging: “handle=<page id>”

The value of the “Paging” field looks like this:



As “Get Record Collection” flow function doesn’t give us access to the response header in any simple way, the better option to get data from the SAP BTP Auditlog service is to use the “HTTP Destination Request” flow function, which gives access to both: data and headers the easy way.

How to use this header field? The logic should go as follows:

  1. Empty the variable containing the data to be displayed
  2. Request data with the “HTTP Destination Request” flow function
  3. Add the body of the response to the variable containing the data to be displayed
  4. If the “paging” field exists in the response header: send next request for data to the Auditlog, but this time add value of the “paging” field to the request path as the last parameter and jump back to step 3
  5. If the “paging” field doesn’t exist in the response header: display the content of the variable containing data

The logic should look like this:

 

How to get access to the response header? Using a formula. We can use the “outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders” in the formula. As the header is a json, it is enough to know the names of fields in the header and then we can check if field exists in the header:

IS_UNDEFINED(outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging

This function returns “true” if the field id undefined, otherwise it returns “false”.

And then, if we know that the field exists, we can get its value simply by its name like this:

outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging

in the “Set App Variable” or “Set Page Variable” flow function.

I use both functions in single formula in the “Set Page Variable” flow function:

IF(IS_UNDEFINED(outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging), "no_paging", outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging)

If the “paging” field is not defined in the header, the formula sets “no_paging” as the variable value. But if the “paging” field is defined, the formula sets its value as the variable value.

entry.title: Connect to Public Cloud API in Node.js via Authorisation Code
entry.content:
Connecting to a Public Cloud API (from Business Accelerator Hub) via Node.js CAP application can be challenging. I hope this blog helps others attempting the same task.

 Prerequisites

• SAP BTP subaccount (Cloud Foundry)
• Service key for the target Public Cloud API
• XSUAA instance bound to your CAP app
• SAP BTP Destination service instance
• Bruno installed for manual testing

 

1. Confirm the API's Auth Options

First, check which authentication methods are available for the API you plan to consume.

In my example I connect to the Specification Management API, but the steps apply to any Public Cloud API.

If the OAuth 2.0 Access Code Flow is listed under “Authentication Methods”, the API supports the authorization-code flow. That flow confirms a user context and usually grants wider authorisations, such as update and POST requests.

(OAuth 2.0 Application Flow corresponds to the client-credentials flow.)

2. Connect manually with Bruno (Good blog on Bruno)

Because our API supports the auth-code flow, we first prove we can log in by calling it via Bruno.

Create a new collection and paste the base URI of your Public Cloud API instance (you’ll find it in the service key in your service instance of the saas application your connecting to).

When you send a test GET request you will probably receive an authorisation error. Configure OAuth 2.0 on the Auth tab

Select Grant type Authorisation Code

Then fill in the below fields using your service key from your service instance

  • Callback URL: <your Public Cloud API hostname>
  • Auth URL:** https://<subdomain>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/authorize
  • Access-Token URL: https://<subdomain>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
  • Client ID / Secret: from the uaa section of the service key

Request the token, pick your identity provider, and Bruno will return an access token. Inspect the scopes there to see what you can do.

3. Connect to the API from Node.js

After the manual check we can now automate the flow in a Node.js service.

3.1 Destination setup

Create a destination that points to the same API endpoint and bind it to your app.

The required scopes and the audience (aud) value are visible inside the Bruno access token.

the Audience should start with the client id of your CAP application on BTP

Once the destination is saved, ensure your application is bound to the Destination service.

3.2 xs-security.json

Add every scope your service needs so the approuter, it will forward it in the user’s JWT: in my example i needed this scope.

{
  "name": "$XSAPPNAME.Spc_Write",
  "description": "Allow modification of specifications."
}

Also reference the scope in authorities (and role templates, if used) and assign the resulting role collection to your user.

3.3 Connect in code

Now time to connect to the API in the code itself.

First, obtain the user’s JWT. This helper below tries every possible source and falls back to LOCAL_USER_JWT in local development:

/** Try every source for a JWT and fall back to LOCAL_USER_JWT. */
function getJwt(capReq) {
  // CAP ≥ 7.3 keeps the raw token here
  if (capReq.user?.jwt) return capReq.user.jwt;

  // Plain HTTP / WebSocket headers
  const hdrs = capReq.http?.req?.headers || {};
  const token =
        hdrs['x-approuter-authorization'] ||   // CF WebSocket
        hdrs.authorization;                    // CF HTTP

  if (token) return token.replace(/^Bearer\s+/, '');
  // Last resort for local dev
  return process.env.LOCAL_USER_JWT;
}

3.3.1 Testing locally

When testing locally we don't have access to the user JWT so we can add it manually to the environment file so we can still test locally, below is the process to get the JWT for user testing (each token lasts about 7 to 8 hours)

Step 1 – Get an auth code
https://<instance>.eu10.authentication.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/authorize
?response_type=code
&client_id=<XSUAA client id of your deployed app>
&redirect_uri=http://localhost
&state=xyz

Paste your version into your browsers address bar, after login you will land on http://localhost/?code=<AUTH_CODE>&state=xyz. Copy the value of AUTH_CODE.

Step 2 – Exchange the code for a JWT

I made the Curl Request inside BAS itself. it will return a number of tokens, we only need the first and biggest one.

curl -v -X POST \
-u '<same client id>' \
--data-urlencode grant_type=authorization_code \
--data-urlencode code=<AUTH_CODE> \
--data-urlencode redirect_uri=http://localhost \
https://<instance>.eu10.authentication.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token

Save the token from the response into .env:

LOCAL_USER_JWT=<paste JWT here>

3.3.2 Call the destination with the JWT

const jwt = getJwt(req);
if (!jwt) req.reject(401, 'No user token found.');

const dest = await getDestination({
  destinationName: '<DestinationName>',
  jwt
});
await executeHttpRequest(dest, {
  method: 'POST',
  url: `/odata/v4/api/specification/v1/${EntityName}`,
  data: v
});

If you reach the destination but receive 401 Unauthorized, your JWT is missing the correct scope—ask the product team which one you need.

Other common pitfall is using the different XSUAA instances to get your JWT for the local run. use your applications XSUAA client since this is the same one your application will check the token against

And that’s it! You should now be able to read from and write to the Public Cloud API. For read-only workloads the client-credentials flow is usually simpler.

If I missed anything or you’d like more details, please comment below—happy to help.

 

## Frequently Asked Questions

### What’s the difference between authorization-code and client-credentials flows?
The authorization-code flow runs in a user context, so it can carry user-level scopes (read, write, update). The client-credentials flow operates with a technical user—perfect for background jobs or read-only integrations.

### Why do I get “401 Unauthorized” after deployment?
Your user’s JWT is probably missing the required scope (e.g., `Spc_Write`). Make sure the scope is listed in xs-security.json, mapped to a role template, and assigned via a role collection in the BTP cockpit.

### Which audience value belongs in my destination?
Use the client ID of your CAP application’s XSUAA instance; it usually starts with `sb-<appName>!t<number>`.

Node.jsSAP Cloud Identity ServicesAPISAP AuthenticatorSAP Fiori CloudSAP Cloud Application Programming ModelSAP Business Application StudioSAP Business Technology PlatformSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition ExtensibilitySAP Business Accelerator HubJavaScriptAPI Management

entry.title: Re: BoE – AP: Why Can’t We Set Maturity Date per Supplier...
entry.content:
Hi @hyik ,

BoE maturity logic is driven by payment terms and payment methods, not supplier master data.

As a workaround:-
Create Vendor-Specific Payment Terms. Define payment terms that reflect BoE maturity (e.g., PT60 = 60 days BoE). Assign the appropriate term to each vendor in their master data. System then derives the BoE due date from the invoice’s payment term.
This is standard, supported, and upgrade-safe.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.

entry.title: Re: Process type is missing
entry.content:
This usually happens when the master data or configuration required for PPDS integration is incomplete or missing.

  1. The process type must be defined in PPDS and linked to the correct transaction type or document category. If you're using a custom document type or a scheduling agreement type not mapped to PPDS, the system won’t find a matching process type.
  2. Ensure that the Scheduling Agreement, Material Master, and Vendor Master are correctly transferred to PPDS via CIF (Core Interface). Missing integration models or inactive queues can block the creation of process types.
  3. PPDS requires a valid PDS or PPM (Production Process Model) for planning. If the subcontracting setup lacks a valid PDS, the system won’t generate a process type.

entry.title: Step-by-Step Guide to Translating Adobe Forms into Other Languages in SAP
entry.content:
Introduction: 

In SAP, when you design Adobe Forms (interactive or print), it's often necessary to provide translations for multi-language support, especially in global organizations. SAP provides the SE63 transaction to translate texts, labels, titles, and other UI elements within Adobe Forms. This guide walks you through the process of translating your form from the source language (e.g., English) to a target language (e.g., German). 

Step-by-Step Setup 

  • Open SE63 Transaction: 
  • Enter SE63 in the SAP command field and hit Enter. 
  • Navigate to Adobe Form Translation: 
  • Click on Other Texts. 
  • Navigate through: 
    Translation → ABAP Objects → Grouped Objects. 

Select Adobe Forms: 

  • Under Grouped Object, double-click PDF-Based Forms. 

Enter Translation Details: 

  • In the next screen, provide the following: 
  • Object Name: Your Adobe form name. 
  • Source Language: The language the form was originally created in (e.g., EN). 
  • Target Language: The language you want to translate to (e.g., DE). 
  • Click on Edit. 

  • Translation Screen: 
  • The translation screen will open. 
  • If it's your first time opening, the target language fields will be blank. 
  • Copy Source Texts (Optional Shortcut): 
  • Click on Copy Source Text if the structure is the same, and you want to use the source as a base. 
  • Activate the Translation: 
  • After editing, click Activate. 

Activate the Translation: 

  • After editing, click Activate. 
  • A green status icon confirms activation. 

Finalize in Layout Designer: 

  • Open Layout of the form using transaction SFP. 
  • Save the layout and go back. 
  • Activate the entire Adobe Form. 

  1. Execute the Form: 
  1. Now, when you run the form in the translated language (e.g., DE), it will reflect the translated text. 

Conclusion: 

Translating Adobe Forms in SAP using SE63 ensures your applications are accessible to users across different regions. With just a few clicks—from identifying the form to copying and editing text—you can effectively provide multilingual support. This method is particularly useful in global projects where form localization is critical. Once activated, your form will display content in the selected target language during execution, offering a seamless user experience.

entry.title: In S/4 Public Edition, how to handle changes on C1 released objects?
entry.content:
The question:
Can we mass-handle C1 exemption requests (create and approve)? Or disable the C1 contract scan on task release?

Why would we want to:
When working in a Public Cloud environment, you're bound to create some custom objects to use. CDS views for example are the bread and butter of the S/4 system. To be able to use those, they have to be released for internal use. That's where the C1 contract comes in, perfect.

A first version was moved to test, so the customer could have a look at where we're going with the development. In the meantime, development continues on the development system. However, if you then change key fields, add parameters and the likes, you break the contract. And indeed, if the object was used by multiple objects and suddenly you introduce a mandatory parameter, it would break.

To prevent this, SAP performs an ATC check on task release. Which in our case returns loads of errors, being all versions of objects we continued working on. There is only one program using these views, which is in the same transport, adjusted and well, but SAP can't assume that is the case, so slaps errors on everything.

These errors can be handled by creating an exemption request. A separate exemption for every error. This generates yet another object in the transport, in which I can explain why it's fine. Then someone else needs to approve those exemptions, you can not do that yourself. Once again, a separate approval for every request.

This being my own development, with all related objects in this transport, everything is just fine. There is no risk. That's why we would want to handle them in mass, or disable the check completely.

entry.title: Re: yaai & yaai_ui – Open-Source AI Tools for ABAP Developers
entry.content:
Hi @tlangner ,
Could you please share your source code?

The easiest way is to use the quickstart. 
https://github.com/christianjianelli/yaai_ui/blob/main/docs/quickstart.md

REPORT yaai_ui_r_quickstart_chat.

PARAMETERS: p_model TYPE c LENGTH 30 LOWER CASE OBLIGATORY DEFAULT 'gpt-4.1'.

CLASS lcl_app DEFINITION.

  PUBLIC SECTION.

    DATA mo_aai_ui_chat TYPE REF TO ycl_aai_ui_chat_v2 READ-ONLY.

    METHODS run.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_app IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD run.

    IF me->mo_aai_ui_chat IS BOUND.
      "Avoid multiple instantiation
      RETURN.
    ENDIF.

    "This example assumes that the API base URL and the API Key are properly configured
    DATA(lo_aai_openai) = NEW ycl_aai_openai( i_model = p_model ).

    "Create a Chat instance passing the AI API you want to use 
    me->mo_aai_ui_chat = NEW #( io_api = lo_aai_openai
                                i_greeting = 'How can I help you today? 😊' ).

    "Display the Chat User Interface
    me->mo_aai_ui_chat->run( ).

  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

DATA o_app TYPE REF TO lcl_app.

INITIALIZATION.

  "Set text for the selection screen fields
  %_p_model_%_app_%-text = 'Model'.

  o_app = NEW lcl_app( ).

AT SELECTION-SCREEN OUTPUT.

  o_app->run( ).


Could you please also check the SAP Logon Options. The chat component requires the Edge browser control. I will update the documentation adding this setting as a requirement.

Thank you!

entry.title: Transport Management in SAP Cloud ERP 3SL Architecture During Upgrades
entry.content:
Introduction

In SAP Cloud ERP's 3-system landscape (3SL) architecture, transport management becomes particularly complex during release upgrades. This Blogpost provides comprehensive guidance on managing transports when systems are at different release levels, addressing common challenges and best practices.

Understanding the 3SL Upgrade Timeline

In the standard three-system landscape, the test system is upgraded three weeks before the development and production systems during each release cycle. This approach provides sufficient time for regression testing before upgrading the remaining systems

Transport Types in SAP Cloud ERP

Before examining specific scenarios, it's essential to understand the three primary transport types:

  •  Customizing Transports: Generated because of Configuration changes via Central Business Configuration or Implementation activities Application.
  •  Developer Extensibility Transports: Created when any kind of ABAP developers extensions created generally via ABAP development tool.
  •  Key User Extensibility Transports: Created as a result of Key user extensions for example Custom field and logic, Custom business objects etc.

Transport Management Scenarios

Scenario 1: Uniform Release Level (N-N-N)

When development, test, and production systems operate at the same release level, transport management follows the standard process:

  • Export all transport types from the development system
  • Import transports into the test system
  • Forward transports to the production system
  • Complete the process by importing into the production system

Scenario 2: Mixed Release Levels (N-N+1-N)

This scenario occurs during the upgrade window when the test system operates at a higher release level than development and production systems.

For Customizing and Developer Extensibility Transports

The standard transport process from Scenario 1 remains applicable.

For Key User Extensibility Transports

Certain objects face import restrictions into higher release systems. For example, SAP Fiori Launchpad Pages (UIPC) during 2502 release (reference: 3560509 - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502 in a 3-system landscape: Release Restriction Note - SAP for Me).

Transports which contain these kinds of objects are shown as outdated. And we have two options for managing them:

Option A: Forward Without Import

Forward the transport from the test system without importing it, and then import it into the productive system

Option B: Re-export After Alignment

After all systems have been upgraded to the same level, you have to re-export the same content again from the development system and transport to test and production system, so as to ensure that the key user extensibility is also in the test system.

Thank you for reading this blog post, hopefully, the blog post was informative and helped you to understand in detail how to manage Transports during upgrade.

Note: You can't import a transport created on release n into release n+2 and higher, which means that you have to recreate the transport in the development system. However, it is not possible to recreate CBC transports. In this case, you have to create a support incident.

Note: To identify the objects not supported for N,N+1 Transports For 2508 Release, Please read the Release Note that generally released 2 Weeks before the T system upgrade.

entry.title: Re: 1. Subsequent Implementation of a Further Accounting...
entry.content:
Hi @sbenfdil ,

Check below config, if its done correctly.

1. Check Currency Settings for the Ledger
Go to Transaction Code: FINSC_LEDGER. Check the ledger assigned to depreciation area 81CH. Ensure Group Currency (type 30) is configured for that ledger.

2. Maintain Parallel Currencies in Asset Accounting
Go to Transaction Code: OADB – Assign Currencies to Company Code. Verify that Group Currency (currency type 30) is listed. Then go to Transaction Code: OABC – Assign Currency Types to Depreciation Areas. Ensure depreciation area 81CH includes currency type 30. If missing, add the currency type with the correct position (e.g., second or third currency).

3. Check Chart of Depreciation and Area Settings
Transaction Code: AO90 or SPRO → Financial Accounting → Asset Accounting → Valuation → Areas → Define Depreciation Areas. Confirm that area 81CH is set to post to the general ledger and has correct posting rules. Make sure currency type 30 is enabled if the area needs to handle group currency postings.

4. Check Customizing for Ledger and Asset Integration
Go to SPRO → Financial Accounting → Asset Accounting → Integration with the General Ledger → Assign Depreciation Areas to Ledgers. Ensure depreciation area 81CH is correctly assigned to the relevant ledger where currency type 30 is active.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh
